text.strong: ‌We would like to learn more about how you learn new school material. You can find a list of different ways of learning here.‌
‌For each way of learning, please indicate how often you use it.‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. I set objectives for myself when I study.
2. I plan my approach to studying.
3. In order to identify gaps in my knowledge, I make a summary of the most important points without using my documents.
4. I ask myself questions about the content to check if I have understood everything.
5. I change my learning plans when I realize that they cannot be implemented.
6. If I notice that my approach to learning is not successful, I change it.

text.strong: ‌We would like to learn more about how you learn. To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements about you?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. When I do not fully understand something, I ask my classmates.
2. I ask my teachers for help when I need it.
3. When I have trouble learning, I ask for help.
4. If I ask my teacher for help, I prefer to receive hints or clues rather than the whole answer.
5. I only ask for help after trying hard to find the solution on my own.

text.strong: ‌This school year, how often did you do the following tasks using <digital resources> outside of school?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. Search for and find relevant information online
2. Assess the quality of information you found online
Write or edit text for a school assignment (e.g. using <Google® Docs™>, <Microsoft® Word>)
4. Create a multi-media presentation (with sound, pictures, or video)
5. Create and edit videos (e.g., <iMovie, Final Cut Pro, InShot>)
6. Create and edit music (e.g. <Audacity, GarageBand>)
7. Create a computer program, macro or app e.g. in <Scratch>, <Logo>, <VBA>,<Java>
8. Collect and record data (e.g., using data loggers, <Microsoft® Access™>, <Google® Form>, <Excel>)
9. Build or edit a webpage (e.g. using <WordPress>)
10. Play digital learning games (e.g. <Atlantis Remixed>, <Duolingo®>)
11. Create shared documents online for collaborative work with others (e.g. using <Google Docs, Dropbox>)
12. Do <science> exercises online
13. Program robots
14. Use virtual or augmented reality
15. Manage and share your work on school assignments or projects online
16. Assess the quality of information generated by Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>)

text.strong: ‌This school year, how often did you do the following tasks using <digital resources> in your school lessons?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. Search for and find relevant information online
2. Assess the quality of information you found online
3. Write or edit text for a school assignment (e.g. using <Google® Docs™>, <Microsoft® Word>)
4. Create a multi-media presentation (with sound, pictures, or video)
5. Create and edit videos (e.g., <iMovie, Final Cut Pro, InShot>)
6. Create and edit music (e.g. <Audacity, GarageBand>)
7. Create a computer program, macro or app e.g. in <Scratch>, <Logo>, <VBA>,<Java>
8. Collect and record data (e.g., using data loggers, <Microsoft® Access™>, <Google® Form>, <Excel>)
9. Build or edit a webpage (e.g. using <WordPress>)
10. Play digital learning games (e.g. <Atlantis Remixed>, <Duolingo®>)
11. Create shared documents online for collaborative work with others (e.g. using <Google Docs, Dropbox>)
12. Do <science> exercises online
13. Program robots
14. Use virtual or augmented reality
15. Manage and share your work on school assignments or projects online
16. Assess the quality of information generated by Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>)

text.strong: ‌To what extent have you been taught at school how to do the following tasks?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. Assess the quality of information you find online
2. Break a complex process into smaller parts
3. Plan tasks by setting out the steps needed to complete them
4. Build models (a simplified representation of how something works) like annotated drawings or maps
5. Solve problems by focusing on the most important parts
6. Make flow diagrams to represent the different parts of a process
7. Use simulations (e.g., virtual science labs) to study scientific phenomena
8. Collect and analyse data to understand a problem or phenomenon
9. Recognise patterns in data
10. Identify common elements and differences across problems
11. Test computer programs and correct errors in them

text.strong: ‌To what extent are you able to do the following tasks when using <digital resources>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌I struggle to do this on my own‌
‌I can do this with a bit of effort‌

label.text: 1. Search for and find relevant information online
2. Assess the quality of information you find online
3. Write or edit text for a school assignment (e.g. using <Google® Docs™>, <Microsoft® Word>)
4. Create a multi-media presentation (with sound, pictures, or video)
5. Create and edit videos (e.g., <iMovie>, <Final Cut Pro>, <InShot>)
6. Create and edit music (e.g. <Audacity>, <GarageBand>)
7. Create a computer program, macro or app e.g. in <Scratch>, <Logo>, <VBA>,<Java>
8. Collect and record data (e.g., using data loggers, <Microsoft® Access™>, <Google® Form>, <Excel>)
9. Build or edit a webpage (e.g. using <WordPress>)
10. Create shared documents online for collaborative work with others (e.g. using <Google Docs, Dropbox>)
11. Use drawing or graphic software and applications
12. Explain how your personal data are being collected and shared by any particular app or website
13. Assess the quality of information generated by Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>, <Google Bard>)

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. I enjoy finding solutions to problems.
2. I feel good when I complete tasks that require a lot of thinking.
3. I like situations where I have to think hard about something.
4. I like complicated problems more than simple problems.
5. I keep working on a problem even if I might not be able to solve it.

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. I am happy to receive comments from my classmates on my school work.
2. I evaluate what I've learned each time I finish studying material.
3. I ask for feedback on my work from someone who is more capable than me (e.g., my teacher).
4. I am open to feedback to improve my school work.
5. I browse through my past outputs to see my progress.

text.strong: ‌Please rate your level of experience with the following programming languages.‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each column.)‌
‌I have never programmed in this language‌
‌I am learning to program in this language, but I haven’t written any program yet‌
‌I have written one or two simple programs‌

label.text: 1. C++ or Java
2. <Scratch>, <Blockly>, or other block-based languages
3. Python, Javascript or other web-based languages
4. HTML, XML, or other markup languages
5. Another programming language not listed above

text.strong: ‌How often do you use <digital resources> during the lessons in the following subjects?‌

text.em: ‌(If you need further explanation of the term “<digital resources>”, please use the help button.) ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌In less than half of the lessons‌
‌In more than half of the lessons‌

label.text: 1. <Science>
2. Mathematics
3. <Test language>
4. <Computer science>,<information technology>,<informatics> or similar lessons
5. Human sciences/Humanities /Social studies (e.g., history, geography, civics, law, economics)
6. Creative arts (e.g., visual arts, music, dance, drama)
7. <Foreign language(s)>
8. <Practical or vocational subjects> (e.g., <mechanics and repair>, <healthcare occupations>, <construction trades>)
9. Other (e.g., <moral/ethics>, <physical education>, <personal and social development>)

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements about your <science teacher>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. My science teacher clearly explains the learning goals for every lesson.
2. My science teacher checks what we already know before teaching a new topic.
3. My science teacher explains her/his thinking when carrying out tasks with us (e.g., analysing a text, designing an experiment).
4. My science teacher gives us advice on learning techniques.
5. My science teacher asks us to identify what resources we will need to complete a task before we get started.
6. My science teacher provides us with materials (e.g., prompts, rubrics, checklists) to monitor our learning progress ourselves.
7. My science teacher gives us advice on how to manage negative emotions related to learning (e.g., frustration, anxiety, boredom).
8. My science teacher asks us to teach a topic to one another.
9. My science teacher asks us to evaluate our own work.
10. My science teacher asks us to evaluate the work of our classmates.
11. My science teacher asks us to carry out challenging learning tasks on our own.

text.strong: ‌Can your science teacher do the following tasks with <digital resources>?‌

text.em: ‌(If you need further explanation of the term “<digital resources>”, please use the help button.) ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌Can do it with a bit of effort‌

label.text: 1. Use multimedia (e.g., PPT, animations) for teaching
2. Use web technologies (websites, blogs) for teaching
3. Use <digital resources> to enhance our learning
4. Use different technologies to make lessons more engaging
5. Solve technical problems when they occur
6. Conduct experiments in virtual labs (e.g. <Labster>, <Phet>)

text.strong: ‌Think about how your <science> teacher uses <digital resources>. To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(If you need further explanation of the term “<digital resources>”, please use the help button.) ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. My Science teacher uses <digital resources> to make the class more interesting.
2. My Science teacher uses <digital resources> to help us understand difficult concepts.
3. My Science teacher uses <digital resources> to give us more freedom in how we do our work.
4. My Science teacher uses <digital resources> because s/he is interested in new technologies.
5. My Science teacher uses <digital resources> to give us personalised assignments.

text.strong: ‌Think about how your <science teacher> has used <digital resources) in class during this school year. How often has he/she used them in the following ways?‌

text.em: ‌(If you need further explanation of the term “<digital resources>”, please use the help button.) ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. To teach the subject to the whole class
2. For our individual work
3. For our group work
4. To test what we have learned
5. To communicate with students

text.strong: ‌Think about the use of <digital resources> for your schoolwork. How much do you agree or disagree with the following statements?‌

text.em: ‌(If you need further explanation of the term “<digital resources>”, please use the help button.) ‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. <Digital resources> help me learn complex things
2. <Digital resources> make the content that I am learning more interesting
3. <Digital resources> distract me from learning
4. <Digital resources> give me more options to choose my study material
5. The use of <Digital resources> disturbs the lessons
6. <Digital resources> help me to express my creativity
7. <Digital resources> help me plan and organise my work
8. <Digital resources> make it easier to work with my classmates

text.strong: ‌How well does each of the following statements below describe you?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. I can handle unusual situations.
2. I can change my behaviour according to the needs required by new situations.
3. I can adapt to different situations even when under stress or pressure.
4. I can adapt easily to a new culture.
5. When encountering difficult situations with other people, I can find a way to resolve the situation.
6. I am capable of overcoming my difficulties in interacting with people from other cultures.

text.strong: ‌You indicated you have experience with computer programming. Where did you learn this knowledge and skills?‌

label.text: In a school club
In <science> class at school
In <Computer science>, <information technology>, <informatics> or similar lessons at school
In other subjects at school
In a club outside of school
Through my friends
Through my siblings
Through my parents
Through other relatives
By myself, e.g., using the internet

text.strong: ‌How often do you use Artificial Intelligence chatbots (e.g. <ChatGPT>) for your school work to do the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: To summarize a text I had to read
To conduct preliminary research on a new topic
To draft texts for writing assignments
To help me learn

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements about your <PISA reading test language> teacher?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: 1. My <PISA reading test language> teacher clearly explains the learning goals for every lesson.
2. My <PISA reading test language> teacher checks what we already know before teaching a new topic.
3. My <PISA reading test language> teacher explains her/his thinking when carrying out tasks with us (e.g., analysing a text).
4. My <PISA reading test language> teacher gives us advice on learning techniques.
5. My <PISA reading test language> teacher asks us to identify what resources we will need to complete a task before we get started.
6. My <PISA reading test language> teacher provides us with materials (e.g., prompts, rubrics, checklists) to monitor our learning progress ourselves.
7. My <PISA reading test language> teacher gives us advice on how to manage negative emotions related to learning (e.g., frustration, anxiety, boredom).
8. My <PISA reading test language> teacher asks us to teach a topic to one another.
9. My <PISA reading test language> teacher asks us to evaluate our own work.
10. My <PISA reading test language> teacher asks us to evaluate the work of our classmates.
11. My <PISA reading test language> teacher asks us to carry out challenging learning tasks on our own.
